channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden Maneuvers to Try to Avoid Devastating Rail Strike
item.description: The Biden administration is considering executive action to try to avoid a shutdown of the nation’s rail network that would harm the economy ahead of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson
item.category: International Assn of Machinists and Aerospace Workers
item.media:credit: Gene J. Puskar/Associated Press
item.media:description: American railways are responsible for transporting much of the chemicals, automobiles, metals, grain and oil that moves around the continent.

item.title: How a Rail Strike Could Reinvigorate Supply Chain Disruption
item.description: If freight trains stop rolling, the result could be chaos for business, shortages for consumers, and fresh momentum for rising prices.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of railroad workers have threatened to go on strike across the country as early as Friday.

item.title: Amtrak Halts Long-Distance Service Over Freight Rail Labor Dispute
item.description: The passenger railroad said trains would operate only if they could complete trips by 12:01 a.m. Friday. Most Northeast Corridor service will continue.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Scott Olson/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Amtrak Car Yard in Chicago. Its cancellations take effect Thursday.

item.title: In Russian Border City of Belgorod, the Ukraine War Feels Real
item.description: In Belgorod, 25 miles from Ukraine, recent losses by Russia’s military have brought home the reality of the war in a way not present elsewhere in the country.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Valerie Hopkins/The New York Times
item.media:description: In Belgorod, Russia, military vehicles marked with the letters Z, V and O, which have become symbols of the Russian invasion, ride through the city.

item.title: Zelensky Visits a City Just Miles From the Front, Underscoring Ukraine’s Gains
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky’s trip to a city reclaimed days ago demonstrated Ukraine’s growing boldness in the wake of Russia’s frantic retreat from the country’s northeast.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made an unannounced visit to Izium, in northeastern Ukraine, on Wednesday, where Russian forces had retreated about a week earlier.

item.title: An Eastern City Under Attack Wonders How Far Ukraine’s Offensive Can Go
item.description: Bakhmut residents who have endured relentless shelling by the Russians watch the Ukrainian forces’ recent victories and weigh whether to stay or to flee.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A tank passing through the center of Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Pakistan Suffers Record Flooding, Turning Villages Into Islands
item.description: The flooding has displaced more than 33 million people, submerging vast areas of Pakistan that are likely to take months to dry out.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boat operators from other regions have come to Sindh Province to make money as ferries for stranded townspeople. They use power lines as landmarks.

item.title: R. Kelly Convicted in Sex Abuse Case Involving Videos of a Teenage Girl
item.description: A Chicago federal jury found the singer, who is already serving a 30-year prison sentence, guilty of charges related to videos he made of himself sexually abusing a 14-year-old.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Robert Chiarito
item.media:credit: Kamil Krzaczynski/Reuters
item.media:description: R. Kelly, shown in 2019, was convicted on Wednesday of sex crimes related to a video he made of him sexually abusing a 14-year-old girl.

item.title: Florida Flies 2 Planeloads of Migrants to Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: The moneyed summer resort became an unlikely arena in the fight over illegal immigration. Republican states have bused thousands of migrants to New York and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Remy Tumin and Eliza Fawcett
item.media:credit: Ray Ewing/The Vineyard Gazette
item.media:description: Migrants and local officials at St. Andrew’s Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard, on Wednesday.

item.title: Adams Wants to Reassess a Shelter System ‘Nearing Its Breaking Point’
item.description: New York City’s homeless system is built around the city’s unique right to shelter. On Wednesday, Mayor Eric Adams said the system should be reconsidered.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since May, 11,000 migrants have entered the city’s shelter system.

item.title: Patagonia Founder Gives Away the Company to Fight Climate Change
item.description: Yvon Chouinard has forfeited ownership of the company he founded 49 years ago. The profits will now be used to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Natalie Behring for The New York Times

item.title: Cosmetics Billionaire Convinced Trump That the U.S. Should Buy Greenland
item.description: Ronald S. Lauder, the Estée Lauder heir, offered himself up as back-channel negotiator to purchase Greenland from Denmark, a new book says. Denmark said no.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Internal studies were issued when President Donald J. Trump suggested the United States could purchase Greenland.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Muddled’ Claims About the Presidential Records Act, Explained
item.description: The former president’s legal team keeps invoking a 1978 law as a basis for various assertions in the dispute over the seized files he was hoarding.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump’s lawyers have claimed that the Presidential Records Act is the only law that governs the dispute over the documents marked as classified.

item.title: Queen’s Coffin Passes Through London Landmarks to Westminster Hall
item.description: King Charles III, his siblings and his sons followed the gun carriage carrying the monarch to Westminster Hall, where she will lie in state.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Peter Nicholls
item.media:description: The procession was one of the most solemn of the public rituals marking the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: How Jomboy Media Rose to Power on ‘Good Vibes Only’
item.description: Jimmy O’Brien’s videos breaking down major events turned Jomboy Media into a big business, but O’Brien still sees himself as a fan. “I don’t plan on changing.”
item.dc:creator: Zach Schonbrun and Desiree Rios

item.title: Britain 3, America 0
item.description: A third woman is now leading Britain. The U.S. has had, um, ....
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: Lindsey Graham’s Unbelievably Cruel Abortion Ban
item.description: Either he doesn’t know how pregnancy works, or he doesn’t care.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: What Conflicted Americans Fear Most From an Abortion Ban
item.description: How the necessity and complexity of life-of-the-mother exceptions is shaping the post-Roe debate.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lines from President Biden’s teleprompter during a speech in Maryland in August.

item.title: Apostle of Black Power
item.description: I’ve urged Black people to reverse the Great Migration and move to the South. Who’s with me?
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.category: The Devil You Know: A Black Power Manifesto (Book)
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Magana/Associated Press

item.title: U.S. Population Growth Has Nearly Flatlined. Is That So Bad?
item.description: Countries around the world are confronting the costs — and potential benefits — of an aging population.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Bokat-Lindell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Ed Jones and Issouf Sanogo, via Getty Images

item.title: China Is Writing the Story of the Climate Future
item.description: But what story is it?
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: What It Took for Stella Levi to Talk About the Holocaust
item.description: How a chance meeting with one of the last Jews of Rhodes changed me.
item.dc:creator: Michael Frank

item.title: China Is Running Covert Operations That Could Seriously Overwhelm Us
item.description: The West isn’t nearly prepared enough for the scale and complexity of China’s all-of-nation covert offensive.
item.dc:creator: Nigel Inkster
item.media:credit: Anson Chan

item.title: Queen Elizabeth, and the Power and Limitations of Inspiring Women
item.description: Changing minds can be powerful, but history shows that changing societies takes more.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Piccadilly Circus in central London on Thursday.

item.title: The Perseverance of Megan Thee Stallion
item.description: The rapper’s rise has been accompanied by outside noise. How has she grown on record, and how have extra-musical narratives shaped her career?
item.media:credit: Ricardo Moraes/Reuters

item.title: Did You Recently Buy an Electric Vehicle? We Want to Hear About It.
item.description: Sales of electric cars are surging as more people become interested in the technology and grow concerned about climate change.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Jae C. Hong/Associated Press
item.media:description: An electric vehicle charging in Los Angeles in August.

item.title: Let’s Talk About E.L. Doctorow’s ‘Ragtime’
item.description: Join the writer Jonathan Dee in a virtual conversation on Sept. 15 about the 1975 novel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: In Dramatic Shift, Right-Wing Bloc Wins Slim Majority in Sweden
item.description: Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson said on Wednesday that she would resign. Despite the success of the far-right Sweden Democrats, they will influence but are not expected to be formally part of the governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Fredrik Sandberg/TT News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The new government is expected to be led by Ulf Kristersson, head of the Moderates, part of a right-wing bloc that won 176 of 349 seats in Parliament.

item.title: Supreme Court Says Yeshiva University Must Allow L.G.B.T. Group as Case Proceeds
item.description: By a 5-to-4 vote, the court refused to block a trial judge’s ruling that required the university to recognize the group under New York City’s anti-discrimination law.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The court’s order meant that the justices will not, for now, address the latest clash between anti-discrimination principles and claims of conscience.

item.title: Mosquito Fire Becomes California’s Largest of Year
item.description: The blaze grew to more than 63,000 acres on Wednesday, overtaking the McKinney fire to become the state’s biggest of 2022.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Jungho Kim for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Mosquito fire burning in Foresthill, Calif., on Wednesday.

item.title: Ohio Judge Temporarily Suspends Abortion Ban
item.description: Abortion was illegal after six weeks of pregnancy, but a judge put the law on hold after abortion rights advocates sued the state.
item.dc:creator: Kate Zernike
item.media:credit: Megan Jelinger/Reuters
item.media:description: Abortion rights supporters at a rally in Columbus, Ohio, in June.

item.title: What Is Brain Fog and How Can I Treat It?
item.description: Researchers are just beginning to understand the cognitive dysfunction that some people experience with Covid-19 and a range of other health issues.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Processed Meat and Health Risks: What to Know
item.description: Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Should You Put on Sunscreen or Foundation First?
item.description: There’s good news and bad news when it comes to sun protection and cosmetics.
item.dc:creator: Caira Blackwell
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Is Driving High as Dangerous as Driving Drunk?
item.description: There’s limited data on how marijuana impacts driving performance, but experts urge caution before getting behind the wheel.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Take on an Empty Stomach.’ How Do You Know When Your Stomach Is Empty?
item.description: Two hours after eating is a crude rule of thumb. A more accurate answer depends on the drugs you are taking and your medical conditions.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.
item.media:credit: Stuart Bradford

item.title: Little Amal Arrives in New York, With a Message of Hope and Humanity
item.description: The 12-foot-tall Syrian refugee puppet traveled from Turkey to Britain last year. Now, she will spend nearly three weeks in the five boroughs taking part in numerous events.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Little Amal at Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday. Her journey from the Syrian-Turkish border started in July 2021, and she has become a symbol of the struggles of refugees.
